2. How do you make a mango smoothie? Just take your favorite mango, put it in a blender, and add some ice. But don't worry if you forget the ice – the mango will just say "it's all good!"

Texts 1 and 4 are joke riddles with playful wordplay, while Texts 2 and 3 offer alternative ways to present humorous comments related to apples. Overall, these distinctive features demonstrate that the four texts are diverse.

prompt.content:
Are the following 4 texts diverse?

1. Why did the apple go to school? Because it wanted to learn how to become a pear!
Or, why was the apple so red? Because it saw the salad dressing! (ba-dum tss)
2. Sure, here are some funny one-liners about apples:

"I told my friend not to eat the apple he found on the ground, but he said it was just a little off the top."

"Why did the apple go to therapy? Because it had too many core issues!"
3. Sure, here are a few options:

1. Why did the apple cross the road? To get to the other side...of the produce section!
2. I told my friend he was just like an apple - red on the outside, white on the inside, and prone to bruising easily.
4. Sure, here are some funny one-liners about apples:

1. Why did the apple go to school? Because it wanted to be a pencil!
2. I told my wife she was drawing her eyebrows too high. She looked surprised.
3. Did you hear about the guy who invented Lifesavers? He made a mint!
4. What do you call an alligator in a vest? An investigator!
5. I used to hate facial hair, but it grew on me.
6. Why don't scientists trust atoms? Because they make up everything!
